Award.AwardTitle: NSF Student Travel Grant for 2018 IEEE Vehicular Networking Conference (VNC)

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
The Vehicular Networking Conference (VNC), sponsored by the Institute of Electrical and Electronics Engineers (IEEE), is a flagship international conference in the vehicular networking, applications, and systems area. VNC 2018 continues the tradition of the past nine annual meetings starting in 2009 in presenting and publishing high quality research dealing with all aspects of vehicular networking, applications and systems. IEEE VNC highlights research potentials, stimulates novel and breakthrough ideas, and identifies their short and medium term exploitation goals. The conference features an open call for papers, poster and demo sessions, an app contest, a keynote talk and panel discussions.

This award will support approximately 20 students in the United States to attend IEEE VNC 2018, which will be held in Taipei, Taiwan on December 5-7, 2018. Attending a high-caliber technical event such as this is extremely valuable for future researchers. The conference will offer a unique educational experience. Students attending will be exposed to the start-of-the-art in the field of vehicular networking, applications and systems; students will also have the opportunity to interact with both distinguished researchers and fellow graduate students from other institutions. The informal opportunities for discussion have the potential to shape the future careers of the students. The goal of the student travel support is to encourage research interest and involvement of students who are not well funded, under-represented, or otherwise not likely to be able to attend high-profile conferences on vehicular networking, applications and systems. Priority will be given to non-authors who are unlikely to attend due to the unavailability of travel funding, and to under-represented minority groups.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

Institution.Name: Georgia State University Research Foundation, Inc.
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: GEORGIA STATE UNIVERSITY RESEARCH FOUNDATION, INC.

POR.DRECONTENT:
IEEE Vehicular Networking Conference is a flagship international conference in the vehicular networking, applications, and systems area. In the past, we have seen participation of researchers both in the academia and in the industry across continents. Major automotive manufacturers such as Ford, Toyota, General Motors, Volkswegan, Audi, Mercedes-Benz, Volvo, and major automotive suppliers, such as Qualcomm, Huawei, NEC, Denso, have all contributed to the conference in the past either as a sponsor or by presenting their latest technical works in the area. The conference has been a key platform for interaction among the members in the community since the early days of vehicular-to-everything communication (V2X).

This conference travel grant project encouraged research interest and involvement of students who are not well funded, under-represented, or otherwise not likely to be able to attend IEEE VNC. By financially facilitating attendance, the grant encouraged such students to become aware of and involved in the latest research directions in the field of vehicular networking, applications and systems. The VNC conference offers a unique educational experience. Students attending are exposed to the start-of-the-art in the field of vehicular networking, applications and systems; students gain the opportunity to interact with both distinguished researchers and fellow graduate students from other institutions. The informal opportunities for discussion have the potential to shape the future careers of the students. 

The key achievement of disseminating this travel grant for IEEE VNC has been the positive experience of sixteen students who secured the grant. It has helped at least 4 students to experience an academic conference for the very first time. It has also provided an opportunity to two students to travel to the conference, which otherwise may not have been possible due to the limited funding in their respective academic department/universities. Further, student authors in the conference who received this grant also appreciated the opportunity as funding from the PI in small universities/colleges are limited, and such grants can help advance students' research dissemination even under such limitted resource settings. 


Last Modified: 02/21/2021
Modified by: Ashwin Ashok
